p: In the above-referred geographical area, as in general in Europe and worldwide, the predominant ethnobotanical research has been an ethnofloristic one [ 11, 12]. Nevertheless, efforts are being devoted toward finding other complementary approaches, such as studies focused on plants used for ailments related to a determined system, and on the validation of the ethnobotanical evidence with chemical or pharmacological data [ 13]. Moreover, the potentially predictive role of molecular phylogeny in bioprospection and in phytochemistry [ 14, 15] and the concept of ethnobotanical convergence [ 16, 17] has opened the way to integrate ethnobotany with genetic (including molecular phylogenetic), genomic (and other “omic” disciplines) and phytochemical approaches [ 18, 19].
